content: The report discusses key base closure developments from the 105th to the 107th Congress, including the signing of legislation in December 2001 (P.L. 107-107) for a new base closure round in 2005. Action on 451 installations scheduled for closure and realignment by previous BRAC commissions was completed by FY2001. The completion of base closure and realignment actions by previous BRAC commissions in FY2001 resulted in significant cost savings. Additional closures were deemed necessary due to defense spending trends, leading to the initiation of a new base closure round in 2005. Secretary of Defense William Cohen released the Quadrennial Defense Review in 1997, calling for two more rounds of base closures in 1999 and 2001 due to the downsizing of DOD's base structure lagging behind its force structure reductions. Force structure had decreased by 33% since the first closure round and was projected to decline by a total of 36% under the QDR. The force structure has decreased by 33% and will decline by a total of 36% under the QDR. Domestic infrastructure will be reduced by 21%. Closing more bases is necessary to achieve a balance between infrastructure and force structure, and to secure significant savings for future readiness and weapons acquisition programs. Without these savings, DOD would struggle to fulfill its missions and responsibilities in the future.
